architecture_metadata.name: Wolf Predation System (Apex Predator)
architecture_metadata.description: Gray wolves as apex predators - population control and trophic cascade initiators
architecture_metadata.ecological_role: KEYSTONE_SPECIES - Apex predator that controls entire ecosystem

components.name: Direct Predation on Deer/Elk
components.description: Wolves kill and consume deer and elk

components.name: Landscape of Fear (Behavioral Cascade)
components.description: Deer alter behavior due to predation risk - avoid vulnerable areas
components.importance: CRITICAL - More important than direct killing for ecosystem restoration

components.name: Deer Population Regulation
components.description: Wolves prevent deer overpopulation through predation

components.name: Habitat Restoration Initiation
components.description: Reduced browsing pressure allows vegetation to regenerate

components.name: Riverbank Stabilization
components.description: Regenerating vegetation stabilizes riverbanks, reduces erosion

components.name: Beaver Population Recovery
components.description: Regenerating young trees provide food and dam materials for beavers

components.name: Ecosystem Biodiversity Recovery
components.description: Vegetation recovery brings back birds, small mammals, pollinators

interactions.description: Wolves actively hunt deer and elk
Wolf presence creates fear-driven behavioral changes in deer
interactions.note: This is MORE important than direct killing for ecosystem restoration

interactions.description: Behavioral changes effectively reduce browsing pressure
Reduced deer density allows vegetation to regenerate
Vegetation recovery restores habitats for many species

notes.trophic_cascade: Wolves → Deer behavior change → Vegetation recovery → Beaver recovery → Wetland creation → Biodiversity increase
notes.yellowstone_case_study: Wolf reintroduction in 1995 led to dramatic ecosystem recovery
notes.landscape_of_fear_importance: Behavioral changes more impactful than direct killing: deer avoid risky areas, creating refugia for plants
notes.missing_system_evidence: Without wolves, all downstream effects collapse: over-browsing, vegetation failure, beaver decline, biodiversity loss
